PyCBD.pipelines.CBDPipeline

class PyCBD.pipelines.CBDPipeline(detector=<PyCBD.checkerboard_detection.checkerboard_detector.CheckerboardDetector object>, expand=False, predict=False, out_of_image=False)[source]

Checkerboard detection pipeline that combines the checkerboard detector and checkerboard enhancer.

Variables:

  • checkerboard_detector – Detector that will be used to detect the checkerboard. The default detector is GeigerDetector, but other detectors can be used as long as they have a detect_checkerboard() method that takes the same inputs and delivers the same outputs as our detector.

  • checkerboard_enhancer – CheckerboardEnhancer for performing checkerboard enhancement. You can change the attributes of the enhancer to fit your needs.

  • expand – Whether to try to expand the detected checkerboard or not by using checkerboard enhancement when some corners remain that have not been assigned to the board. This can also be used to bridge large occlusions. When using the expansion it is recommended that you provide a checkerboard size when performing the detection, so the enhancer does not needlessly try to expand when the entire checkerboard has already been detected.

  • predict – Whether to refine the corner positions with Gaussian processes or not. This also fills in occlusions and can expand the checkerboard beyond the image borders.

  • out_of_image – Whether to include predicted points beyond the limits of the image during the refinement step.

  • plot_pipeline_steps – Whether to plot intermediate results of the pipeline.

  • max_iterations – Sets the max_iterations attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

  • max_expansion_factor – Sets the max_expansion_factor attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

  • max_dist_factor – Sets the max_dist_factor attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

  • must_plot_gp_stuff – Sets the must_plot_gp_stuff attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

  • must_plot_iterations – Sets the must_plot_iterations attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

  • dewarped_res_factor – Sets the dewarped_res_factor attribute of the checkerboard_enhancer.

__init__(detector=<PyCBD.checkerboard_detection.checkerboard_detector.CheckerboardDetector object>, expand=False, predict=False, out_of_image=False)[source]

Class constructor.

Parameters:

  • detector (any) – An instance of the detector that should be used for checkerboard detection. Our detector is used by default but other detectors can be used as long as they have a detect_checkerboard method that takes the same inputs and returns the same outputs as our detector.

  • expand (bool) – Whether to try to expand detected checkerboard or not.

  • predict (bool) – Whether to use our refinement step and fill in occlusions or not.

  • out_of_image (bool) – Whether to include predicted points beyond the limits of the image during the refinement step.

Methods

__init__([detector, expand, predict, ...])

Class constructor.

detect_checkerboard(image[, size])

Perform checkerboard detection on an image.

dewarp_image(image, board_uv, board_xy[, ...])

Remove lens and perspective distortion from the image.
detect_checkerboard(image, size=None)[source]

Perform checkerboard detection on an image.

Parameters:

  • image (ndarray[Any, dtype[TypeVar(ScalarType, bound= generic, covariant=True)]]) – Image to perform detection on. This should be a numpy array that represents a grayscale or color image in BGR format.

  • size (Optional[Tuple[int, int]]) – The size of the checkerboard, i.e., the amount of inner corner rows and columns (rows, columns). This is an optional argument that allows the detector to verify whether the entire checkerboard has been found or not and whether the checkerboard xy positions are absolute or relative. It is recommended to provide the checkerboard size when performing the checkerboard expansion so the algorithm doesn’t needlessly try to expand when all rows and columns have already been found.

Return type:

Tuple[int, ndarray[Any, dtype[float64]], ndarray[Any, dtype[float64]]]

Returns:

result: to what degree the checkerboard detection was successful, 0 means the detection failed, 1 means the xy coordinates are relative, 2 means the xy coordinates are absolute; board_uv: image coordinates (u, v) of detected corners assigned to the checkerboard; board_xy: local coordinates (x, y) of the detected corners assigned to the checkerboard.

dewarp_image(image, board_uv, board_xy, use_stored=True)[source]

Remove lens and perspective distortion from the image.

This method can either be performed separately, in which case new Gaussian processes need to be fitted to the checkerboard, or after performing checkerboard detection with predict set to True, where the stored Gaussian processes can be used instead.

Parameters:

  • image (ndarray[Any, dtype[TypeVar(ScalarType, bound= generic, covariant=True)]]) – Original image that needs to be dewarped.

  • board_uv (ndarray[Any, dtype[TypeVar(ScalarType, bound= generic, covariant=True)]]) – Image corner coordinates (u, v).

  • board_xy (ndarray[Any, dtype[TypeVar(ScalarType, bound= generic, covariant=True)]]) – Local corner coordinates (x, y).

  • use_stored (bool) – Whether to reuse the stored Gaussian processes or fit new ones.

Return type:

ndarray[Any, dtype[TypeVar(ScalarType, bound= generic, covariant=True)]]

Returns:

The dewarped image.
